questions.text: The most common cardiac manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is:
questions.solution:
The most common cardiac manifestation manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is Pericarditis. 

The most frequent site of cardiac involvement in RA is the pericardium. Although less than 10% exhibit clinical manifestations of pericarditis.

Mitral regurgitation is the most common valvular abnormality in RA, occurring at a higher frequency than the general population.

Other extra-articular manifestations are:

  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Pleuritis, Interstitial Lung disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Felty's syndrome
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

Related Pearl: Most commons conditions in Rheumatoid Arthritis

questions.text: A young male patient presents to the physician with steatorrhea associated with chronic pancreatitis. Stool examination of the patient shows increased fecal fat and decreased fecal elastase. Other test used for diagnosis of this condition is  ______.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pancreatic exocrine insufficiency. Lundh test, pancreolauryl test, and N-benzoyl-l-tyrosyl-p-aminobenzoic acid (NBT-PABA) are all tests for the pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.

Tests for Exocrine Pancreas 

  • Directly measuring pancreatic secretion in response to a standardized stimulus.
    • The stimulus to secretion can be
      • Physiological, e.g., ingestion of a test meal, as in the Lundh test
      • Pharmacological, e.g., intravenous injection of a hormone, such as secretin or cholecystokinin (CCK).
      • Duodenal intubation has to be performed with a triple-lumen tube so that the gastric and duodenal juices can be aspirated, and a non-absorbable marker, such as polyethylene glycol, is used to assess the completeness of the aspiration.
  • The nitroblue tetrazolium–para-aminobenzoic acid (NBT–PABA) test provides an indirect measure of pancreatic function
    • The substance is administered orally and degraded in the gut by a pancreatic enzyme, and the breakdown product (PABA) is absorbed by the intestine and excreted in the urine; its urinary level is measured.
  • The pancreolauryl test works on a similar principle.
    • These tests are cheap and easy to perform, but are non-specific, especially following gastrectomy and in conditions that may alter gastrointestinal transit and intestinal absorptive capacity.
  • Measurement of the fecal elastase 1 in the stool is simple, specific, and now widely used.
    • Interpretation:
      • Above 200 μg/g feces is normal
      • Between 100 and 200 μg/g: mild to moder­ate pancreatic insufficiency
      • Below 100 μg/g: establishes the diagnosis of severe pancreatic exocrine insufficiency
    • The fecal fat and weight estimation test measures the stool content of fat after a nutritional intake of 100 g of fat per day during 3 days. If the stool fat content exceeds 7 g/day, the diag­nosis of steatorrhea is established.

questions.text: Which technique of female sterilization is portrayed in the following image?
questions.solution:
The technique of sterilization portrayed in the image is the Pomeroy technique.

The most popular technique of tubal ligation is the Pomeroy technique.

Procedure :

  • The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut (any rapidly absorbing sutures) and excised.
  • There should be an adequate margin between the suture and the cut end to prevent the cut ends of the tube from slipping out of the suture.
  • The cut ends of the tube are inspected to visualize the tubal lumen; this confirms resection of a full thickness of the tube.
  • As the tubal stumps heal, the suture absorbs and the ends fall apart

The operation is simple, requires short hospitalization and is surgically reversible.

The failure rate is only 0.4% and it is mainly due to spontaneous canalization.

questions.text: A  4 year old child is brought to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following can be used in the treatment of of this patient?
questions.solution:
The urine turning to black in colour on exposure to air is suggestive of alkaptonuria which occurs due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase enzyme. Nitisinone can be used in the treatment of alkaptonuria.

  • Nitisinone, formerly known as NTBC, inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD) (early step in the tyrosine degradation pathway) and efficiently reduces homogentisic acid production in alkaptonuria.
  • Treatment of arthritis is symptomatic.
  • In presymptomatic individuals, treatment using a combination of nitisinone with phenylalanine and tyrosine restricted diet can be tried.

Alkaptonuria due to the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

The condition has three characteristic symptoms:

  • Black ochronotic pigmentation (Alkapton bodies) of cartilage and collagenous tissue (in adulthood)
  • Homogentisic aciduria (patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing)
  • Large joint arthritis (in adulthood)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a metaphyseal lesion?
questions.solution:
Chondroblastoma is an epiphyseal lesion.

Following are the metaphyseal lesions:

  • Enchondroma
  • Osteochondroma (Option A)
  • Nonossifying fibroma (NOF) (Option D)
  • Bone cyst
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Cortical desmoid (Option B)
  • Giant cell tumor in children

questions.text: A 24 year-old female comes to the clinic with complaints of amenorrhea, fatigue and weakness. Upon eliciting history, she reveals that she is always worried about gaining weight. Her mother complains that she doesn't eat well. Her BMI is 16.6. Laboratory findings in this patient will show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of anorexia nervosa. Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone is seen in a patient of anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder that is characterized by self-induced starvation to a significant degree, drive for thinness or a morbid fear of fatness, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms resulting from starvation.

Investigations in anorexia nervosa:

  • Complete blood count: Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis
  • Serum electrolyte: Hypokalemic alkalosis (Purging)
  • Fasting serum glucose: Often low (emaciated phase) (Option D)
  • Serum salivary amylase: Often elevated (if the patient is vomiting)
  • ECG: ST segment and T-wave changes (secondary to electrolyte disturbances)
  • Hypotension and bradycardia
  • High serum cholesterol level (Option A)
  • Endocrine changes (caused by the underweight):
    • Amenorrhea
    • Hypothyroidism (Option B)
    • Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone

questions.text: According to Modified Mallampati grading, which class does this fall under?
questions.solution:
The given figure falls under Class III of Modified Mallampati classification as only the base of the uvula and soft palate are visible ; it implies it is a difficult intubation situation.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used in the assessment of difficult airway.

Modified Mallampati grading:

  • Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis upon mouth opening and tongue protrusion
  • Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula, pillars visible
  • Class II: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible
  • Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible
  • Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all

The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without speaking or saying “ahh.”

Classes 3 and 4 are difficult intubation situations.

Percentage of glottic opening (POGO score) and Cormack–Lehane (CL) classification is broadly used to describe laryngeal view during direct laryngoscopy.

Seshagiri Rao Mallampati (1941 – ) is an Indian-origin American anesthesiologist. The ‘original’ Mallampati scoring system had only three stages and was published in 1985.

questions.text: For chlorination of a community’s well water, the water sample from the well was tested using Horrock’s apparatus. It was observed that the 4th cup showed a blue color after addition of the starch-iodine indicator. How much bleaching powder will be required to disinfect 7735 litres of the well water?
questions.solution:
The dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 liters of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows a distinct blue color.

In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 liters of water is (4 x 2) = 8 grams.

Since 7735/455 = 17. The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 7735 litres of water = 8 x 17 = 136 grams.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • The Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodine indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodine indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 L of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: A 7-year- old child presents with scanty, foul smelling ear discharge. On examination, perforation was seen in pars flaccida of tympanic membrane. The treatment of choice in this patient is _____
questions.solution:
Scanty, purulent, foul smelling is seen in Atticoantral type of CSOM where surgery i.e, Modified radical mastoidectomy is the treatment of choice.

Other options :

  • Myringotomy with grommet insertion is done in serous otitis media with impending rupture of the tympanic membrane. (Option A)
  • Medical management followed by myringoplasty or tympanoplasty once the ear is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics is the treatment of choice for tubotympanic type of CSOM. (Option C and D)

questions.text: Which disease is this cataract associated with?
questions.solution:
Snowflake/Snowstorm cataract is typically observed in diabetes mellitus.

Diabetic cataract

  • Hyperglycemia is reflected in a high level of glucose in the aqueous humor, which diffuses into the lens.
  • Here, glucose is metabolized into sorbitol, which accumulates within the lens, resulting in secondary osmotic overhydration.

Snowflake/Snowstorm cataract is also observed in Down's syndrome.

questions.text: The venom of a pit viper is:
questions.solution:
Vipers are vasculotoxic. 

The venom causes enzymatic destruction of cell walls and coagulation disorders.

The main site of action are endothelial cells of blood vessels. There is hemolysis of red blood cells as well.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a specimen received after staging laparotomy for an ovarian mass revealed the following. Which of the following is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The histological picture shows Call–Exner bodies which are seen in cases of granulosa cell tumor, small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. 

Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle.

Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin are associated with granulosa cell tumors.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumors.

Clinical significance:

  • May elaborate large amounts of estrogen (functional tumor of the ovary)
  • May behave like low-grade malignancies

questions.text: Which among the following causes contraction of mesangial cells?
questions.solution:
PGF2 causes contraction of the mesangial cells. The other agents mentioned in the options cause relaxation of the mesangial cells.

Agents causing relaxation of mesangial cells (mnemonic - DAnCE)

  • Dopamine
  • ANP
  • cAMP
  • PGE2

Angiotensin II is an important regulator of mesangial contraction, and there are angiotensin II receptors in the glomeruli.

questions.text: The antitubercular drug most likely to cause optic neuritis is _______
questions.solution:
The antitubercular drug that is most likely to cause optic neuritis is ethambutol. 

 

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action Blocks mycolic acid synthesis. Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis. Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane. Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.
